title: Klezmer
text:
Klezmer () is an instrumental musical tradition of the <a href="Ashkenazi%20Jews">Ashkenazi Jews</a> of <a href="Central%20Europe">Central</a> and <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a>. The essential elements of the tradition include dance tunes, ritual melodies, and virtuosic improvisations played for listening; these would have been played at weddings and other social functions. The musical genre incorporated elements of many other musical genres including <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman</a> (especially <a href="Greek%20music">Greek</a> and <a href="Romanian%20music">Romanian</a>) music, <a href="Baroque%20music">Baroque music</a>, <a href="Germany">German</a> and <a href="Slavic%20people">Slavic</a> folk dances, and religious Jewish music. As the music arrived in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, it lost some of its traditional ritual elements and adopted elements of American <a href="big%20band">big band</a> and popular music. Among the European-born klezmers who popularized the genre in the United States in the 1910s and 1920s were <a href="Dave%20Tarras">Dave Tarras</a> and <a href="Naftule%20Brandwein">Naftule Brandwein</a>; they were followed by American-born musicians such as Max Epstein, <a href="Sidney%20Beckerman%20%28musician%29">Sid Beckerman</a> and Ray Musiker. 
After the destruction of Jewish life in Eastern Europe during the <a href="Holocaust">Holocaust</a>, and a general fall in the popularity of klezmer music in the United States, the music began to be popularized again in the late 1970s in the so-called Klezmer Revival. During the 1980s and onwards, musicians experimented with traditional and experimental forms of the genre, releasing fusion albums combining the genre with <a href="jazz">jazz</a>, <a href="Punk%20music">punk</a>, and other styles.
Etymology.
The term , as used in the <a href="Yiddish%20language">Yiddish language</a>, has a <a href="Hebrew%20language">Hebrew</a> etymology: "klei", meaning "tools, utensils or instruments of" and "zemer", "melody"; leading to "k'lei zemer" , meaning "<a href="musical%20instruments">musical instruments</a>". This expression would have been familiar to literate Jews across the diaspora, not only <a href="Ashkenazi%20Jews">Ashkenazi Jews</a> in <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a>. Over time the usage of "" in a Yiddish context evolved to describe musicians instead of their instruments, first in <a href="Bohemia">Bohemia</a> in the second half of the sixteenth century and then in <a href="Poland">Poland</a>, possibly as a response to the new status of the musicians who were at that time forming professional guilds. Previously the musician may have been referred to as a () or other terms. After the term became the preferred term for these professional musicians in Yiddish-speaking Eastern Europe, other types of musicians were more commonly known as or .
It was not until the late 20th century that the word "Klezmer" became a commonly known <a href="English%20language">English language</a> term. During that time, through <a href="metonymy">metonymy</a> it came to refer not only to the musician but to the musical genre they played, a meaning which it had not had in Yiddish. Early 20th century recording industry materials and other writings had referred to it as Hebrew, Jewish, or Yiddish dance music, or sometimes using the Yiddish term "Freilech music" ("Cheerful music"). 
Twentieth century Russian scholars sometimes used the term Klezmer; <a href="Ivan%20Lipaev">Ivan Lipaev</a> did not use it, but <a href="Moisei%20Beregovsky">Moisei Beregovsky</a> did when publishing in Yiddish or <a href="Ukrainian%20language">Ukrainian</a>. 
The first postwar recordings to use the term "klezmer" to refer to the music were <a href="The%20Klezmorim">The Klezmorim</a>'s "East Side Wedding" and "Streets of Gold" in 1977/78, followed by <a href="Andy%20Statman">Andy Statman</a> and Zev Feldman's "Jewish Klezmer Music" in 1979.
Musical elements.
Style.
The traditional style of playing Klezmer music, including tone, typical <a href="Cadence%20%28music%29">cadences</a>, and <a href="ornamentation%20%28music%29">ornamentation</a> sets it apart from other genres. Although Klezmer music emerged out of a larger Eastern European Jewish musical culture that included <a href="hazzanut">Jewish cantorial music</a>, <a href="Hasidic%20Judaism">Hasidic</a> <a href="Nigun">Nigns</a>, and <a href="Yiddish%20theatre">Yiddish theatre</a> music, it also borrowed from the surrounding folk musics of Central and Eastern Europe and from cosmopolitan European musical forms. Therefore it evolved into an overall style which has recognizable elements from all of those other genres.
Few klezmer musicians before the late nineteenth century had formal musical training, but they inherited a rich tradition with its own advanced musical techniques, each musician had their understanding of how the style should be "correctly" performed. The usage of these ornaments was not random; the matters of "taste", self-expression, <a href="Variation%20%28music%29">variation</a> and restraint were and remain important elements of how to interpret the music. 
Klezmer musicians apply the overall style to available specific techniques on each melodic instrument. They incorporate and elaborate the vocal melodies of Jewish religious practice, including "<a href="Hazzan">khazones</a>", "<a href="Davening">davenen</a>", and paraliturgical song, extending the range of human voice into the musical expression possible on instruments. Among those stylistic elements that are considered typically "Jewish" in Klezmer music are those which are shared with cantorial or <a href="Hasidic%20Judaism">Hasidic</a> vocal ornaments, including "<a href="dreydlekh">dreydlekh</a>" ("tear in the voice") and imitations of sighing or laughing ("laughter through tears"). Various Yiddish terms were used for these vocal-like ornaments such as ("<a href="Krekhts">Krekhts</a>", "groan" or "moan"), (, "wrinkle" or "fold"), and (, "pressure" or "stress"). Other ornaments such as <a href="Trill%20%28music%29">trills</a>, <a href="Grace%20note">grace notes</a>, <a href="Appoggiatura">appoggiaturas</a>, <a href="Pedal%20point">pedal notes</a>, <a href="Mordent%20%28music%29">mordents</a>, <a href="Slide%20%28musical%20ornament%29">slides</a> and typical Klezmer cadences are also important to the style. In particular, the cadences which draw on religious Jewish music identify a piece more strongly as a Klezmer tune, even if its broader structure was borrowed from a non-Jewish source. Unlike in <a href="Classical%20music">Classical music</a>, <a href="vibrato">vibrato</a> is used more sparingly, and is treated as another type of ornament.
The accompaniment style of the accompanist or orchestra could be fairly impromptu, called (, holding onto).
Historical repertoire.
The repertoire of Klezmer musicians was very diverse and tied to specific social functions and dances, especially of the traditional wedding. These melodies might have a non-Jewish origin, or have been composed by a Klezmer, but only rarely are they attributed to a specific composer. Generally Klezmer music can be divided into two broad categories: music for specific dances, and music for listening (at the table, in processions, ceremonial, etc.)
Orchestration.
Klezmer music is an instrumental tradition, without much of a history of songs or singing. In Eastern Europe, Klezmers did traditionally accompany the vocal stylings of the <a href="Badchen">Badchen</a> (wedding entertainer), although their performances were typically improvised couplets and the calling of ceremonies rather than songs. (The importance of the Badchen gradually decreased by the twentieth century, although they still continued in some traditions.)
As for the klezmer orchestra, its size and composition varied by time and place. The Klezmer bands of the eighteenth and early nineteenth century were small, with roughly three to five musicians playing <a href="Woodwind%20instrument">Woodwind</a> or <a href="String%20instrument">String</a> instruments. Another common configuration in that era was similar to <a href="Music%20of%20Hungary">Hungarian bands</a> today, typically a lead violinist, second violin, <a href="Cello">cello</a>, and <a href="Cimbalom">Cimbalom</a>. In the mid-nineteenth century, the <a href="Clarinet">Clarinet</a> started to appear in those small Klezmer ensembles as well. By the last decades of the century, in Ukraine, the orchestras had grown larger, averaging seven to twelve members, and incorporating <a href="Brass%20instrument">Brass instruments</a> and up to twenty for a prestigious occasion. (However, for poor weddings a large Klezmer ensemble might only send three or four of its junior members.) In these larger orchestras, on top of the core instrumentation of strings and woodwinds, <a href="Cornet">cornets</a>, <a href="Clarinet">C clarinets</a>, <a href="Trombone">trombones</a>, <a href="Contrabass">a contrabass</a>, a large Turkish drum, and several extra violins. The inclusion of Jews in tsarist army bands during the 19th century may also have led to the introduction of typical military band instruments into klezmer. With such large orchestras, the music was arranged so that the bandleader soloist could still be heard at key moments. In <a href="Galicia%20%28Eastern%20Europe%29">Galicia</a>, and <a href="Belarus">Belarus</a>, the smaller string ensemble with cimbalom remained the norm into the twentieth century. American Klezmer as it developed in dancehalls and wedding banquets of the early twentieth century had a more complete orchestration not unlike those used in popular orchestras of the time. They use a <a href="clarinet">clarinet</a>, <a href="saxophone">saxophone</a>, or <a href="trumpet">trumpet</a> for the melody, and make great use of the <a href="trombone">trombone</a> for slides and other flourishes.
The melody in Klezmer music is generally assigned to the lead violin, although occasionally the flute and eventually clarinet. The other instrumentalists provide harmony, rhythm, and some counterpoint (the latter usually coming from the second violin or viola). The <a href="clarinet">clarinet</a> now often played the melody. Brass instruments—such as the French valved <a href="cornet">cornet</a> and keyed German <a href="trumpet">trumpet</a>—eventually inherited a counter-voice role. Modern klezmer instrumentation is more commonly influenced by the instruments of the 19th century military bands than the earlier orchestras. 
Percussion in early 20th-century klezmer recordings was generally minimal—no more than a <a href="Woodblock%20%28instrument%29">wood block</a> or <a href="snare%20drum">snare drum</a>. In Eastern Europe, percussion was often provided by a drummer who played a <a href="frame%20drum">frame drum</a>, or "poyk", sometimes called <a href="baraban%20%28drum%29">baraban</a>. A poyk is similar to a <a href="bass%20drum">bass drum</a> and often has a cymbal or piece of metal mounted on top, which is struck by a beater or a small cymbal strapped to the hand.
Melodic modes.
Western, Cantorial, and Ottoman music terminology.
Klezmer music is a genre that developed partly in the <a href="Western_culture%23Music">Western musical tradition</a> but also in the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, and is primarily an oral tradition which does not have a well-established literature to explain its <a href="Mode%20%28music%29">modes</a> and modal progression. But, as with other types of Ashkenazic Jewish music, it has a complex system of modes which were used in its compositions. Many of its melodies do not fit well in the <a href="Major%20key">major</a> and <a href="Minor%20key">minor</a> terminology used in Western music, nor is the music systematically <a href="Microtonal%20music">microtonal</a> in the way that <a href="Middle%20Eastern%20music">Middle Eastern music</a> is. <a href="Nusach%20%28Jewish%20music%29">Nusach</a> terminology, as developed for <a href="Hazzan">Cantorial music</a> in the nineteenth century, is often used instead, and indeed many Klezmer compositions draw heavily on religious music. But it also incorporates elements of <a href="Baroque%20music">Baroque</a> and Eastern European folk musics, making description based only on religious terminology incomplete. Still, since the <a href="Klezmer%20revival">Klezmer revival</a> of the 1970s, the terms for Jewish prayer modes are the most common to describe the those used in klezmer. The terms used in <a href="Yiddish%20language">Yiddish</a> for these modes include <a href="Nusach%20%28Jewish%20music%29">Nusach</a> (); (), "manner, mode of life" which describes the typical melodic character, important notes and scale; and (), a word meaning "taste" which was commonly used by <a href="Moisei%20Beregovsky">Moisei Beregovsky</a>.
Beregovsky, who was writing in the <a href="Stalinist%20era">Stalinist era</a> and was constrained by having to downplay Klezmer's religious aspects, did not use the terminology of Synagogue modes, except in some early work in 1929. Instead, he relied on German-inspired musical terminology of major, minor, and "other" modes, which he described in technical terms. In his 1940s works he noted that the majority of the klezmer repertoire seemed to be in a minor key, whether <a href="Natural%20minor">Natural minor</a> or others, that around a quarter of the material was in <a href="Freygish">Freygish</a>, and that around a fifth of the repertoire was in a <a href="Major%20key">Major key</a>.
Another set of terminology sometimes used to describe klezmer music is that of the <a href="Turkish%20makam">Makams</a> used in <a href="Ottoman%20music">Ottoman</a> and other <a href="Middle%20Eastern%20music">Middle Eastern musics</a>. This approach dates back to Idelsohn in the early twentieth century, who was very familiar with <a href="Middle%20Eastern%20music">Middle Eastern music</a>, and has been developed in the past decade by Joshua Horowitz.
Finally, some Klezmer music, and especially those composed in the United States from the mid-twentieth century onwards, may not be composed with these traditional modes, but rather built around <a href="Chords%20in%20music">chords</a>.
Description.
Because there is no agreed-upon, complete system for describing modes in Klezmer music, this list is imperfect and may conflate concepts which some scholars view as separate. Another problem in listing these terms as simple eight-note (<a href="Heptatonic%20scale">Heptatonic</a>) <a href="Scale%20%28music%29">scales</a> is that it makes it harder to see how Klezmer melodic structures can work as five-note <a href="Tetrachord">tetrachords</a>, how parts of different modes typically interact, and what the cultural significance of a given mode might be in a traditional Klezmer context.
History.
Europe.
Development of the genre.
The <a href="Bible">Bible</a> has several descriptions of orchestras and <a href="Levites">Levites</a> making music, but after the destruction of the <a href="Second%20Temple">Second Temple</a> in 70 <a href="Common%20Era">CE</a>, many <a href="Rabbi">Rabbi</a>s discouraged musical instruments. Therefore, while there may have been Jewish musicians in different times and places since then, the "Klezmer" arose much more recently. The earliest written record of the use of the word was identified by <a href="Isaac%20Rivkind">Isaac Rivkind</a> as being in a Jewish council meeting from <a href="Krakow">Krakow</a> in 1595. They may have existed even earlier in <a href="Prague">Prague</a>, as references to them have been found as early as 1511 and 1533. It was in the 1600s that the situation of Jewish musicians in <a href="Poland">Poland</a> improved, as they gained the right to form <a href="Guild">Guild</a>s ("Khevre"), and therefore to set their own fees, hire Christians, and so on. Therefore over time this new form of professional musician developed new forms of music and elaborated this tradition across a wide area of Eastern European Jewish life. The rise of <a href="Hasidic%20Judaism">Hasidic Judaism</a> in the sixteenth century and onwards also contributed to the development of klezmer, due to their emphasis on dancing and wordless melodies as a component of Jewish practice.
The Eastern European klezmer profession (1700–1930s).
The nineteenth century also saw the rise of a number of klezmer violin virtuosos who combined the techniques of classical violinists such as <a href="Ivan%20Khandoshkin">Ivan Khandoshkin</a> and of <a href="Bessarabia">Bessarabia</a>n folk violinists, and who composed dance and display pieces that became widespread even after the composers were gone. Among these figures were Aron-Moyshe Kholodenko "<a href="Pedotser">Pedotser</a>", Yosef Drucker "<a href="Stempenyu">Stempenyu</a>", Alter Goyzman "Alter Tshudovner" and <a href="Josef%20Gusikov">Josef Gusikov</a>.
Unlike in the United States, where there was a robust Klezmer recording industry, there was relatively less recorded in Europe in the early twentieth century. The majority of European recordings of Jewish music consisted of Cantorial and <a href="Yiddish%20Theatre">Yiddish Theatre</a> music, with only a few dozen known to exist of Klezmer music. These include violin pieces by artists such as Oscar Zehngut, <a href="H.%20Steiner">H. Steiner</a>, Leon Ahl, and Josef Solinski; flute pieces by S. Kosch, and ensemble recordings by <a href="Belf%27s%20Rumanian%20Orchestra">Belf's Rumanian Orchestra</a>, the Russian-Jewish Orchestra, Jewish Wedding Orchestra, and Titunshnayder's Orchestra.
Klezmer in the late Russian empire and Soviet era.
The loosening of restrictions on Jews in the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a>, and their newfound access to academic and conservatory training, created a class of scholars who began to reexamine and evaluate klezmer using modern techniques. <a href="Abraham%20Zevi%20Idelsohn">Abraham Zevi Idelsohn</a> was one such figure, who sought to find an ancient <a href="Middle%20East">Middle Eastern</a> origin for Jewish music in the diaspora. There was also new interest in collecting and studying Jewish music and folklore, including Yiddish songs, folk tales, and instrumental music. An early expedition was by <a href="Joel%20Engel%20%28composer%29">Joel Engel</a>, who collected folk melodies in his birthplace of <a href="Berdyansk">Berdyansk</a> in 1900. The first figure to collect large amounts of klezmer music was <a href="Susman%20Kiselgof">Susman Kiselgof</a>, who made several expeditions to the <a href="Pale%20of%20Settlement">Pale of Settlement</a> from 1907 to 1915. He was soon followed by other scholars such as <a href="Moisei%20Beregovsky">Moisei Beregovsky</a> and <a href="Sofia%20Magid">Sofia Magid</a>, <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet</a> scholars of Yiddish and klezmer music. Most of the materials collected in those expeditions are now held by the <a href="Vernadsky%20National%20Library%20of%20Ukraine">Vernadsky National Library of Ukraine</a>.
 Beregovsky, writing in the late 1930s, lamented how little scholars knew about the range of playing technique and social context of Klezmers from past eras, except for the late nineteenth century which could be investigated through elderly musicians who still remembered it.
Jewish music in the Soviet Union, and the continued use of Klezmer music, went through several phases of official support or censorship. The officially-supported Soviet Jewish musical culture of 1920s involved works based on or satirizing traditional melodies and themes, whereas those of the 1930s were often "Russian" cultural works translated into a Yiddish context. After 1948, Soviet Jewish culture entered a phase of repression, meaning that Jewish music concerts, whether tied to Hebrew, Yiddish, or instrumental Klezmer were no longer allowed to be performed.
 Moisei Beregovsky's academic work was shut down in 1949 and he was arrested and deported to <a href="Siberia">Siberia</a> in 1951. The repression was eased in the mid-1950s as some Jewish and Yiddish performances were allowed to return to the stage once again. However, the main venue for Klezmer has always been traditional community events, weddings, and not the concert stage or academic institute; those traditional venues were repressed along with Jewish culture in general, according to anti-religious Soviet policy.
United States.
Early American klezmer (1880s–1910s).
The first klezmers to arrive in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> followed the first large waves of Eastern European Jewish immigration which began after 1880, establishing themselves mainly in large cities like New York, Philadelphia and Boston. Klezmers—often younger members of klezmer families, or less established musicians—started to arrive from the Russian Empire, the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Romania">Kingdom of Romania</a> and <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>. Some of them found work in restaurants, dance halls, union rallies, wine cellars, and other modern venues in places like New York's <a href="Lower%20East%20Side">Lower East Side</a>. But the major source of income for klezmer musicians seems to have remained weddings and <a href="Simcha">Simchas</a>, as in Europe. Those early generations of klezmers are much more poorly documented than those working in the 1910s and 1920s; many never recorded or published music, although some are remembered through family or community history, such as the Lemish klezmer family of <a href="Ia%C8%99i">Iași</a>, <a href="Romania">Romania</a> who arrived in Philadelphia in the 1880s and established a klezmer dynasty there.
Big band klezmer orchestras (1910s–1920s).
The vitality of the Jewish music industry in major American cities attracted ever more klezmers from Europe in the 1910s. This coincided with the development of the recording industry, which recorded a number of these klezmer orchestras. By the time of the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, the industry turned its attention to ethnic dance music and a number of bandleaders were hired by record companies such as <a href="Edison%20Records">Edison Records</a>, <a href="Emerson%20Records">Emerson Records</a>, <a href="Okeh%20Records">Okeh Records</a>, and the <a href="Victor%20Recording%20Company">Victor Recording Company</a> to record 78 rpm discs. The first of these was <a href="Abe%20Elenkrig">Abe Elenkrig</a>, a barber and cornet player from a klezmer family in Ukraine whose 1913 recording (From the Wedding) has been recognized by the <a href="Library%20of%20Congress">Library of Congress</a>.
Among the European-born klezmers recording during that decade were some from the Ukrainian territory of the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a> (Abe Elenkrig, <a href="Dave%20Tarras">Dave Tarras</a>, <a href="Shloimke%20Beckerman">Shloimke Beckerman</a>, <a href="Joseph%20Frankel%20%28musician%29">Joseph Frankel</a>, and <a href="Israel%20J.%20Hochman">Israel J. Hochman</a>), some from <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austro-Hungarian</a> <a href="Galicia%20%28Eastern%20Europe%29">Galicia</a> (<a href="Naftule%20Brandwein">Naftule Brandwein</a>, <a href="Harry%20Kandel">Harry Kandel</a> and Berish Katz), and some from <a href="Romania">Romania</a> (<a href="Abe%20Schwartz">Abe Schwartz</a>, <a href="Max%20Leibowitz">Max Leibowitz</a>, <a href="Joseph%20Moskowitz">Joseph Moskowitz</a>).
The mid 1920s also saw a number of popular novelty "Klezmer" groups which performed on the radio or <a href="Vaudeville">Vaudeville</a> stages. These included <a href="Joseph%20Cherniavsky">Joseph Cherniavsky</a>'s Yiddish-American Jazz Band, whose members would dress as parodies of <a href="Cossacks">Cossacks</a> or <a href="Hasidic%20Judaism">Hasidim</a>. Another such group was the Boibriker Kapelle, which performed on the radio and in concerts trying to recreate a nostalgic, old-fashioned <a href="Galicia%20%28Eastern%20Europe%29">Galician</a> Klezmer sound. With the passing of the <a href="Immigration%20Act%20of%201924">Immigration Act of 1924</a> which greatly restricted Jewish immigration from Europe, and then the onset of the <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a> by 1930, the market for Yiddish and klezmer recordings in the United States saw a steep decline, which essentially ended the recording career of many of the popular bandleaders of the 1910s and 1920s, and made the Large klezmer orchestra less viable.
Celebrity clarinetists.
Along with the rise of klezmer "big bands" in the 1910s and 1920s, a handful of Jewish <a href="clarinet">clarinet</a> players who had led those bands became celebrities in their own right, with a legacy that lasted into subsequent decades. The most popular among these were <a href="Naftule%20Brandwein">Naftule Brandwein</a>, <a href="Dave%20Tarras">Dave Tarras</a>, and <a href="Shloimke%20Beckerman">Shloimke Beckerman</a>.
Klezmer revival.
In the mid-to-late 1970s there was a klezmer revival in the United States and Europe, led by <a href="Giora%20Feidman">Giora Feidman</a>, <a href="The%20Klezmorim">The Klezmorim</a>, Zev Feldman, <a href="Andy%20Statman">Andy Statman</a>, and the <a href="Klezmer%20Conservatory%20Band">Klezmer Conservatory Band</a>. They drew their repertoire from recordings and surviving musicians of U.S. klezmer. In particular, clarinetists such as Dave Tarras and Max Epstein became mentors to this new generation of klezmer musicians. In 1985, <a href="Henry%20Sapoznik">Henry Sapoznik</a> and Adrienne Cooper founded <a href="KlezKamp">KlezKamp</a> to teach klezmer and other Yiddish music.
The 1980s saw a second wave of revival, as interest grew in more traditionally inspired performances with string instruments, largely with non-Jews of the United States and Germany. Musicians began to track down older European klezmer, by listening to recordings, finding transcriptions, and making field recordings of the few klezmorim left in Eastern Europe. Key performers in this style are <a href="Joel%20Rubin">Joel Rubin</a>, <a href="Budowitz">Budowitz</a>, Khevrisa, Di Naye Kapelye, Yale Strom, The Chicago Klezmer Ensemble, The Maxwell Street Klezmer Band, the violinists <a href="Alicia%20Svigals">Alicia Svigals</a>, Steven Greenman, Cookie Segelstein and <a href="Elie%20Rosenblatt">Elie Rosenblatt</a>, flutist Adrianne Greenbaum, and <a href="tsimbl">tsimbl</a> player <a href="Pete%20Rushefsky">Pete Rushefsky</a>. Bands like Brave Old World, Hot Pstromi and The Klezmatics also emerged during this period.
In the 1990s, musicians from the San Francisco Bay Area helped further interest in klezmer music by taking it into new territory. Groups such as the New Klezmer Trio inspired a new wave of bands merging klezmer with other forms of music, such as <a href="John%20Zorn">John Zorn</a>'s Masada and Bar Kokhba, Naftule's Dream, Don Byron's Mickey Katz project and violinist <a href="Daniel%20Hoffman%20%28violinist%29">Daniel Hoffman's</a> klezmer/jazz/Middle-Eastern fusion band Davka. The New Orleans Klezmer All-Stars also formed in 1991 with a mixture of New Orleans funk, jazz, and klezmer styles.
Interest in klezmer has been sustained and supported by such well-known <a href="avant-garde">avant-garde</a> <a href="jazz">jazz</a> musicians as John Zorn and <a href="Don%20Byron">Don Byron</a>, who sometimes blend klezmer with <a href="jazz">jazz</a>.
Starting in 2008, "The Other Europeans" project, funded by several EU cultural institutions, spent a year doing intensive field research in <a href="Moldavia">Moldavia</a> under the leadership of Alan Bern and scholar Zev Feldman. They wanted to explore klezmer and <a href="L%C4%83utari">lautari</a> roots, and fuse the music of the two "other European" groups. The resulting band now performs internationally.
A separate klezmer tradition had developed in Israel in the 20th century. Clarinetists Moshe Berlin and Avrum Leib Burstein are known exponents of the klezmer style in Israel. In order to preserve and promote klezmer music in Israel, Burstein founded the Jerusalem Klezmer Association, which has become a center for learning and performance of Klezmer music in the country.
Popular culture.
In music.
While traditional performances may have been on the decline, many Jewish composers who had mainstream success, such as <a href="Leonard%20Bernstein">Leonard Bernstein</a> and <a href="Aaron%20Copland">Aaron Copland</a>, continued to be influenced by the klezmeric idioms heard during their youth (as <a href="Gustav%20Mahler">Gustav Mahler</a> had been). <a href="George%20Gershwin">George Gershwin</a> was familiar with klezmer music, and the opening clarinet glissando of <a href="Rhapsody%20in%20Blue">Rhapsody in Blue</a> suggests this influence, although the composer did not compose klezmer directly. Some clarinet stylings of swing jazz bandleaders <a href="Benny%20Goodman">Benny Goodman</a> and <a href="Artie%20Shaw">Artie Shaw</a> can be interpreted as having been derived from klezmer, as can the "freilach swing" playing of other Jewish artists of the period such as trumpeter <a href="Ziggy%20Elman">Ziggy Elman</a>.
At the same time, non-Jewish composers were also turning to klezmer for a prolific source of fascinating thematic material. <a href="Dmitri%20Shostakovich">Dmitri Shostakovich</a> in particular admired klezmer music for embracing both the ecstasy and the despair of human life, and quoted several melodies in his <a href="chamber%20music">chamber</a> masterpieces, the <a href="Piano%20Quintet%20%28Shostakovich%29">Piano Quintet in G minor, op. 57</a> (1940), the <a href="Piano%20Trio%20No.%202%20%28Shostakovich%29">Piano Trio No. 2 in E minor, op. 67</a> (1944), and the <a href="String%20Quartet%20No.%208%20%28Shostakovich%29">String Quartet No. 8 in C minor, op. 110</a> (1960).
The compositions of Israeli-born composer <a href="Ofer%20Ben-Amots">Ofer Ben-Amots</a> incorporate aspects of klezmer music, most notably his 2006 composition "Klezmer Concerto". The piece is for klezmer clarinet (written for Jewish clarinetist <a href="David%20Krakauer">David Krakauer</a>), string orchestra, harp and percussion.
In visual art.
The figure of the klezmer, as a romantic symbol of nineteenth century Jewish life, appeared in the art of a number of twentieth century Jewish artists such as <a href="Anatoli%20Lvovich%20Kaplan">Anatoli Lvovich Kaplan</a>, <a href="Issachar%20Ber%20Ryback">Issachar Ber Ryback</a>, <a href="Marc%20Chagall">Marc Chagall</a>, and <a href="Chaim%20Goldberg">Chaim Goldberg</a>. Kaplan, making his art in the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>, was quite taken by the romantic images of the Klezmer in literature, and in particular in <a href="Sholem%20Aleichem">Sholem Aleichem</a>'s <a href="Stempenyu">Stempenyu</a>, and depicted them in rich detail.
In literature.
In Jewish literature, the klezmer was often represented as a romantic and somewhat unsavory figure. However, in nineteenth century works by writers such as <a href="Mendele%20Mocher%20Sforim">Mendele Mocher Sforim</a> and <a href="Sholem%20Aleichem">Sholem Aleichem</a> they were also portrayed as great artists and virtuosos who delighted the masses. Klezmers also appeared in non-Jewish Eastern European literature, such as in the epic poem <a href="Pan%20Tadeusz">Pan Tadeusz</a>, which depicted a character named Jankiel Cymbalist, or in the short stories of <a href="Leopold%20von%20Sacher-Masoch">Leopold von Sacher-Masoch</a>. In <a href="George%20Eliot">George Eliot</a>'s <a href="Daniel%20Deronda">Daniel Deronda</a> (1876), the <a href="German%20Jews">German Jewish</a> music teacher is named Herr Julius Klesmer. The novel was later adapted into a Yiddish musical by <a href="Avram%20Goldfaden">Avram Goldfaden</a> titled (1908).
